title: What will be the 2020 industry-wide average cost of Li-ion batteries used in battery-powered electric vehicles?
possible_answers: More than $130 but less than $145 per kWh
correct_answer: More than $130 but less than $145 per kWh
preds: Assuming about $137 per kWh per Bloomberg

One measure is at $137. Doesn't necessarily mean the Mack institute will come up with the same, but this one is dead middle of the middle bucket so seems likely. https://about.bnef.com/blog/battery-pack-prices-cited-below-100-kwh-for-the-first-time-in-2020-while-market-average-sits-at-137-kwh/
Owners I've met gave me the data needed to answer.

"BNEF estimates that the average battery cost in 2020 was $137/kWh and it is going to reach $100/kWh by 2023: “Lithium-ion battery pack prices, which were above $1,100 per kilowatt-hour in 2010, have fallen 89% in real terms to $137/kWh in 2020. By 2023, average prices will be close to $100/kWh, according to the latest forecast from research company BloombergNEF (BNEF).” "Of note, many electric buses in China use LFP battery chemistries, which are now making their way into electric cars. "Most notably, Tesla recently switched to LFP batteries in its Model 3 standard Range Plus produced in China."

According to the world's premier survey of Lithium-ion battery prices, the BloombergNEF, the average price of a battery in 2019 was $156/kWh. This marks an 87 percent decline since the technology was first introduced in 2010. This makes for an average of a 9.6 percent decline per year. [1] Assuming this same rate of decline, we can extrapolate an average price of $141.02/kWh in 2020. But many industry experts, including the Concern of Atomic Scientists, predict that cost-cutting will become more capital intensive in the next decade. [2] For the sake of argument, let's half that decline rate to 4.8 percent. This brings us to an upperbound of $148.52/kWh. On the other hand, a volume weighted analysis by BNEF shows an average price decline in excess of 17 percent per annum. If we use this figure, we forecast a figure of $129.48/kWh. My working range or base then is $129.48-148.52. This is a range of $19.04. $0.52 of this ( $115-$130) makes up 2.7 percent of the total range
The next $15 comprises 79 percent of the range
$3.52 of this is encompasses 18 percent of the range This is the way I thought about it. I know there's got to be a math guy out there having an anyuersm about my logic so please annihilate it in the comments. I would really appreciate the feedback. [1] https://about.bnef.com/blog/battery-pack-prices-fall-as-market-ramps-up-with-market-average-at-156-kwh-in-2019/#:~:text=By%202023%2C%20average%20prices%20will,research%20company%20BloombergNEF%20(BNEF).&text=BNEF's%202019%20Battery%20Price%20Survey,will%20fall%20below%20%24100%2FkWh.
[2]https://www.ucsusa.org/resources/ev-batteries#:~:text=Electric%20vehicle%20battery%20cost,kilowatt%2Dhour%20(kWh).
[3]https://about.bnef.com/blog/behind-scenes-take-lithium-ion-battery-prices/

With annual 16% decline trend it's unlikely to stay at current rate. Equally unlikely to fall so dramatically to below $115. If the trending reduction continues, most likely place to land is around $136 but with covid impact on battery demand and expense pressure on r&d there may be less incentive to lower the cost of the packs. Conversely, there seems to be an equally chance that in order to boost sales, production costs are trimmed, central govt provides increased support to industry and production costs fall resulting in a lower cost per pack and a better deal for the customer

Not sure how to approach, so I started with facts.  Since we are relying on this methodology, we start with US$161 as the cost per kWh in 2019.  And the decline rate seems to be steady, 16% decline, kind of like a Moore's Law for batteries (which doesn't exist, at least no exponential one).  While there's no exact corollary, there has been a trend line in improvement in improving chemistries for production of kWh that helps drives prices per kWh downward, 5-8% (https://www.edn.com/do-lithium-ion-batteries-follow-moores-law/).  McKinsey, one of the sources in the spreadsheet provided, made a pretty good estimate back in 2012, that missed, ($200 by 2020, $160 by 2025; a lot once inflation is accounted for) but I thought it was interesting (https://www.mckinsey.com/business-functions/sustainability/our-insights/battery-technology-charges-ahead). In any case, the simple forecast is taking the $161 2019 figure and reducing it to $135 for 2020.  However, with the world under Shelter-In-Place order, demand for commodities should fall, causing the prices of the chemicals necessary for building the batteries to drop further.  So I'm going with 40% in 115-130 and 60% in 130-145, as I think given the trend of 16% has been pretty steady, it should be around 135, but with drop in global output (GDP), prices will fall, so there's a good chance of the price falling below $130, as calculated by the methodology.   I thought I would get a forecast out first with my initial thoughts, then research further on component pricing, and articles on those, for follow-up forecasts.

Assume 16% decline is going to continue, so maximum weight around 135.  Also, if Tesla was really at $130 already in 2019, the rest of the industry needs to get there in order to compete.  Very difficult to imagine prices going up or staying the same and having the industry average go down by 30% in one year is very unlikely. The biggest uncertainty is probably around the data available to make the assessment.

Average for 2019 was 161/kwh, with an annual decline of 13%. += 5 percentage points is 132 to 148, almost entirely in the middle bucket. allocate a little more for less than 115/kwh for an unexpected breakthrough

Projected decline: 16%  Declines per bracket: 
1: more than 29%
2: Between 19% and 28%
3: Between 18% and 10%
4: Between 9% and 1%
5: less than 1% or increase in price The trend of decreases of 16% seems fairly stable, but I do not have sufficient economic expertise to account for potential effects of the corona crisis. Also, I was not able to quickly find the raw data for the diagram in the article, such that I had to eyeball the per year deviation from the regression line (which is likely to distort the results because of the logarithmic plot) It does seem plausible that there was an increase in price both in 2012, 2015 and 2019. The ones in 2012 and 2019 happened after years with unusally low prices.  In partiular, decreases of over 30% look plausible for both 2011 and 2018. As the base rates for the other brackets are harder to eyeball, I start with the plausible base rates of 13% for the first and 19% for the last bracket. As 2019 did not see a unusually large decrease in price, but stagnation followed such decreases in two of three cases, I reduce the probability of the last bracket to 10%. This leaves me with 77%, of which I distribute 36% to the middle bracket, as it includes the projected 16 percent decline, and 24% to the second bracket, as it is a lot closer to the projected decline than the fourth bracket, which receives 17%.  Without looking at the crowd forecast, I get 13|24|36|17|10.
Correcting for the crowd forecast of 5|17|52|22|4 , I arrive at 11|23|39|18|9

It appears from the logarithmic graph of prices as though the average is calculated as a mean of all the figures sourced. But I don't think this is taking into account that Tesla – who produce something like 50% of the batteries appear to have the cheapest production price by far. So if it were a weighed average based on the level of production, then I think the number would be lower. For example, if Tesla produce batteries at $100 per kWh and ten other companies produce batteries at $200 per kWh, you may add 10x200 to 1x100 and average that out between 11 producers to get a mean total average of $190 per kWh. But if Tesla produce 50% of the batteries at $100 per kWh and the other 50% are being produced at $200 per kWh, then your weighted average would be $150 per kWh for the industry. So this makes a big difference. It's worth noting that even in the study linked above, there's no clarity on the price being for the cell, module or pack. Tesla will be holding their Battery and Powertrain Investor Day on 20(ish) April 2020. Expect them to announce either a current price around or under $100 per kWh, or a roadmap to this. In fact, if they are announcing how they will scale to TWh of production, expect a roadmap to a far cheaper price. Plus, if Tesla alone can scale to TWh of batteries, that weighted average argument would bring the cost down significantly. Depending on what Tesla announce in April, I'll be back to refine my number, because I anticipate they'll be increasing their contribution to the global total production significantly. Compound that with increased EV sales (by percentage, not total because this year will be terrible for car sales) and I think prices will drop quite a lot.
